How did the women treat the men then? Was there a bit of harassment going on there?
Absolutely. What the men gave the women, the women gave back to the men, a hundred times more.
But when it came to production, and we've got to get this job out, our livelihoods depends on this,
you see women and men working hand in hand. If I was to just describe a suit that is made from,
that comes from the design to the cutting room, from the cutting room to the conveyor,
from the conveyor to the finishing hand section to the steaming, the pressing and the folding to go,
you're talking about every person has to work to get that started and finished,
because until it's finished and it's inspected, you don't get paid. So everybody is working together,
and to see this at its finest was Bull Week. Bull Week was the week before Christmas,
and the week before the annual holidays. I don't remember any other holidays.
Christmas was the big holiday, the women management knew we needed extra money in our wage packets,
because kids and toys, and then of course the annual holiday. It wasn't the same for Easter.
Nobody had big Easter holidays, you didn't have things. Not that I can remember anyway,
but Bull Week was something else. You know, when I laugh about it now, it was called Bull,
like a bull in a cow, a bull, Bull Week. Well, you know, here we are now today in 2014,
and I'm educated enough to know about trading and stock exchange, and I've seen so many, many programmes
about how they take this bullish attitude to stocks and shares, and you see this bull on the advertisements.
And you know what, if you go back to 1962, that's basically where it started from, and probably years before that.
It meant that you had to double your production this week, no matter what it took this week,
because next week you're going on holiday. So for instance, if you had your Christmas holiday,
and you had Christmas Eve and Boxing Day, and I can't remember long holidays, but even so,
even if it was two or three days, and all depends of course, if Christmas fell on a Saturday and Sunday,
that was magical for factory workers, because if Christmas Eve, if Christmas Day fell on a Sunday,
you've got a day in lieu for that. So if Christmas fell on a Saturday and a Sunday,
you'd have Christmas for the Saturday, you'd have Boxing Day for the Sunday, so everybody would say,
oh my God, this year we're getting four days off.
Can I just check, and this was paid leave?
Oh yes, paid, oh yes, absolutely. But so to get the bonus, to get your nice big hefty,
and I'm talking about hefty bonuses, all the stops and whistles were pulled out.
I wonder sometimes what the management used to think. They probably thought,
how the hell can't they work like this every day? Well you didn't, you couldn't keep up the pace.
But the week before, oh let me tell you something, and I'm talking about women would make provisions,
and babysitters would come in and they'd say, you know, I'm not home to make dinner,
and you're going to have to do this. We are working every hour that we can get,
because we're going to go on holiday. It would be fabulous, and all the whistles,
and I'm talking about still laughing, joking, having fun, but those machines ran.
They didn't stop. Overtime went on sometimes to 10 o'clock at night.
We had unions, of course, union and management came up with a time,
but they worked. As long as the work was there, the management also knew that there was going to be a two week stoppage,
when nothing was going on. So let's see what we can put out to fill in this two week gap.
Women came through, and the men. When was the two week stoppage?
Well, it was the annual holiday. The entire, all of Wales.
Last week in July, first week in August, that's when all factories closed down, even in London.
So polycos would shut? Yes, all the mines were closed. This was the annual mining holiday,
and everything closed. If the miners were out of work, then everything ran according to the miners,
so the factories closed down. Well, it was stupid. If the miners were going to have two weeks off from work,
